Topics.Strand: Component 1: The study of religions: beliefs, teachings and practices

Sub_topics.description: Understand the concept of Dhamma (Dharma) in Buddhism: what it means (the Buddha’s teaching/ultimate truth/natural law), how it functions as guidance for practice and understanding reality, and its significance for Buddhists’ beliefs and lived practice.

Understand dependent arising (paticcasamuppada): the teaching that phenomena arise in dependence on conditions; how it explains causation, suffering and the cycle of existence; and its significance for Buddhist views of reality and liberation.
Know and apply the Three Marks of Existence focusing on anicca (impermanence): meaning, examples, and how insight into impermanence supports Buddhist practice and the path to liberation.

Know and apply the Three Marks of Existence focusing on anatta (no fixed self): meaning (no permanent, independent soul/self), implications for identity and attachment, and significance for Buddhist practice and liberation.

Know and apply the Three Marks of Existence focusing on dukkha (unsatisfactoriness/suffering): meaning, how it characterises conditioned existence, and why recognising dukkha motivates Buddhist practice.

Understand the Theravada account of human personality as the Five Aggregates (skandhas): form, sensation, perception, mental formations, consciousness; how these explain personhood without a permanent self; and their importance for Buddhist understanding and practice.

Understand Mahayana teaching of sunyata (emptiness): meaning (lack of inherent existence), how it relates to interdependence and compassion, and its importance for Mahayana perspectives on wisdom and liberation.

Understand Mahayana beliefs about the possibility of attaining Buddhahood and Buddha-nature: what Buddha-nature means, how it supports the ideal of universal potential for awakening, and its significance for Mahayana practice and aims.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Theravada vs Mahayana ideals: Arhat and Bodhisattva
Sub_topics.description: Compare human destiny ideals in Theravada and Mahayana: Arhat (perfected person) ideal vs Bodhisattva ideal; what each aims for, how they shape practice/ethics, and why they matter within Buddhist traditions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Pure Land: Buddhahood and the Pure Land
Sub_topics.description: Understand beliefs about Buddhahood and the Pure Land: what ‘Pure Land’ refers to, how it relates to salvation/liberation in some Mahayana traditions, and its significance for hope, devotion and practice.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Buddha’s birth and life of luxury
Sub_topics.description: Know key events in the Buddha’s life and why they matter: his birth and early life of luxury, and how this background contributes to understanding his renunciation and teaching.

Know the Four Sights—illness, old age, death, holy man—as presented in Jataka 075: what each represents, how they prompted Siddhartha’s search for truth, and their significance for Buddhist understanding of suffering and renunciation.
Understand the Buddha’s period of asceticism: what he practised, why he rejected extreme asceticism, and how it leads to the Middle Way as a key Buddhist teaching.

Understand the Buddha’s Enlightenment: what ‘awakening’ means in Buddhism, its outcomes (insight into reality and end of ignorance), and why it is foundational for Buddhist beliefs, Dhamma and Sangha.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: First Noble Truth: dukkha and types of suffering
Sub_topics.description: Know the First Noble Truth: dukkha (suffering/unsatisfactoriness), including different types of suffering described in Buddhist teaching, and how recognising dukkha frames the Buddhist spiritual problem.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Second Noble Truth: samudaya and Three Poisons
Sub_topics.description: Know the Second Noble Truth: causes of suffering (samudaya), including the Three Poisons—ignorance, greed, hate—and how these drive craving and unwholesome action leading to continued dukkha.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Third Noble Truth: tanha cessation and nibbana/nirvana
Sub_topics.description: Know the Third Noble Truth: the end of craving (tanha) and the goal of nibbana/nirvana; understand differing interpretations of nibbana/nirvana and Enlightenment within Buddhism and their significance for liberation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Fourth Noble Truth: Eightfold Path and Threefold Way (Dhammapada 190–191)
Sub_topics.description: Know the Fourth Noble Truth: the Eightfold Path (magga) as the path to nibbana/nirvana; understand its presentation as the Threefold Way—ethics (sila), meditation (samadhi), wisdom (panna)—and be able to reference Dhammapada 190–191 in support.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Buddhist places of worship (temples, shrines, monasteries, viharas, gompas)
Sub_topics.description: Understand the nature, use and importance of Buddhist places of worship: temples, shrines, monasteries (viharas), halls for meditation/learning (gompas); key features including Buddha rupa, artefacts and offerings; and how these support devotion, community and practice.

Understand puja as devotional ritual: significance and role in the home and in the temple; common elements including chanting (as devotion and mental concentration), mantra recitation, and use of malas; and how puja expresses Buddhist values and supports practice.

Know aims, significance and methods of meditation focusing on Samatha (concentration/tranquillity), including mindfulness of breathing: how it develops calm, focus and mental discipline and supports progress on the path.
Know aims, significance and methods of meditation focusing on Vipassana (insight), including zazen: how insight practice develops wisdom about impermanence/non-self/suffering and supports liberation.

Understand visualisation practices in meditation: visualising Buddhas and Bodhisattvas, purposes (devotion, cultivating qualities, concentration), and significance within Mahayana/Vajrayana-influenced traditions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Death and mourning rituals (Theravada; Japan; Tibet)
Sub_topics.description: Understand practices and significance of ceremonies and rituals associated with death and mourning: in Theravada communities and in Japan and Tibet; how beliefs about rebirth/kamma/compassion shape rites and community responses to death.

Know the celebrations, origins and significance of Wesak and its importance for Buddhists in Great Britain today; how it commemorates key events in the Buddha’s life and supports communal identity and practice.

Know the celebrations, origins and significance of Parinirvana Day and its importance for Buddhists in Great Britain today; how it commemorates the Buddha’s death/final nirvana and influences reflection on impermanence and liberation.

Understand Buddhist ethical teaching on kamma (karma) and rebirth: how intentional action has consequences shaping rebirth and experience; how this supports moral responsibility and motivation for practice.
Understand karuna (compassion): meaning, why it is central to Buddhist ethics, and how it influences moral choices and attitudes towards suffering beings.
Understand metta (loving-kindness): meaning, practices that cultivate it (e.g., meditation), and how it shapes ethical behaviour and relationships.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Five moral precepts: do not take life
Sub_topics.description: Know the first moral precept (do not take life): meaning, how Buddhists apply it (non-harming/ahimsa), and implications for ethical decisions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Five moral precepts: do not take what is not given
Sub_topics.description: Know the second moral precept (do not take what is not given): meaning (non-stealing), application and ethical implications.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Five moral precepts: do not misuse the senses
Sub_topics.description: Know the third moral precept (do not misuse the senses): meaning (often sexual misconduct/overindulgence), application and ethical implications for conduct and self-control.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Five moral precepts: do not speak falsehoods
Sub_topics.description: Know the fourth moral precept (do not speak falsehoods): meaning (truthfulness/right speech), how it guides communication and ethical behaviour.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Five moral precepts: do not take intoxicants
Sub_topics.description: Know the fifth moral precept (do not take intoxicants that cloud the mind): meaning, reasons (protect mindfulness and moral awareness), and ethical implications.
Know the Mahayana six perfections (paramitas) focusing on generosity: what it involves and how individuals develop it as part of the Bodhisattva path.
Know the Mahayana six perfections focusing on morality: what it involves and how individuals cultivate ethical discipline as part of spiritual development.
Know the Mahayana six perfections focusing on patience: meaning (forbearance), how it is developed, and its role in compassion and resilience.
Know the Mahayana six perfections focusing on energy: meaning (effort/enthusiasm), how it supports sustained practice and moral action.
Know the Mahayana six perfections focusing on meditation: how meditative discipline is cultivated to develop concentration and insight on the Bodhisattva path.
Know the Mahayana six perfections focusing on wisdom: meaning (insight into reality/emptiness), and how individuals develop wisdom in themselves as part of liberation for self and others.

Topics.Strand: Component 1: The study of religions: beliefs, teachings and practices

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Nature of God: omnipotent, loving, just
Sub_topics.description: Understand Christian beliefs about the nature of God as omnipotent, loving and just; how these attributes are expressed in Christian teaching and worship; and their implications for moral life and belief.

Understand the Christian problem of evil and suffering: why evil/suffering challenges belief in an omnipotent, loving, just God; and how different Christians may respond (theodicies/faith responses) using religious teaching and reasoning.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Oneness of God and the Trinity
Sub_topics.description: Know Christian belief in the oneness of God and the Trinity: Father, Son and Holy Spirit; how Trinitarian belief shapes Christian understanding of God and worship.

Understand different Christian beliefs about creation, including the role of the Word and Spirit, with reference to John 1:1–3 and Genesis 1:1–3; be able to explain how these texts inform beliefs about God as Creator and relationship with creation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Afterlife: resurrection and life after death
Sub_topics.description: Understand Christian beliefs about the afterlife, including resurrection and life after death, and why belief in life after death is important for Christian living and hope.
Understand Christian beliefs about judgement, heaven and hell: meanings, differing views among Christians, and the impact of these beliefs on moral decision-making and faith.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Incarnation and Jesus as Son of God
Sub_topics.description: Understand beliefs about the incarnation (God becoming human) and Jesus as the Son of God; why this is central to Christianity and its implications for salvation and worship.
Know Christian beliefs about Jesus’ crucifixion, resurrection and ascension; significance for overcoming sin and death; and influence on Christian festivals and faith.
Understand Christian teaching on sin, including original sin: what sin is, how original sin is understood, and why it matters for the need for salvation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Means of salvation: law, grace and Spirit
Sub_topics.description: Understand Christian beliefs about the means of salvation, including the roles of law, grace and the Spirit; how Christians understand being saved and transformed.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Role of Christ in salvation: atonement
Sub_topics.description: Understand the role of Christ in salvation including the idea of atonement: how Jesus’ death and resurrection reconcile humans with God; differing understandings of atonement where relevant.
Know liturgical worship: features (set structure/rites), significance for Christian community, and how the Bible may be used within liturgical worship.
Know non-liturgical worship: features (less formal structure), significance and examples, including how the Bible may be used.
Know informal worship: features (spontaneous/modern forms), significance, and use of the Bible within informal settings.
Understand private worship: practices (personal devotion), significance for individual faith, and possible forms (Bible reading, prayer).
Know the Lord’s Prayer: content/themes, why it is significant for Christians, and how it is used in worship and personal devotion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Prayer: set prayers and informal prayer
Sub_topics.description: Understand set prayers and informal prayer: differences, examples, and significance for Christian relationships with God and community worship.
Know what a sacrament is in Christianity: outward sign of inward grace, role in worship, and significance as channels of God’s grace (noting denominational differences).
Understand the sacrament of baptism and its significance for Christians (initiation, cleansing from sin, belonging to Church), and how it is practised.
Compare infant baptism and believers’ baptism: how each is conducted, theological reasons for each practice, and their significance for Christian identity and commitment.
Understand differing Christian beliefs about infant baptism: arguments for and against, denominational perspectives, and implications for views of faith, salvation and Church membership.
Understand the sacrament of Holy Communion/Eucharist: purpose and significance for Christians (remembrance, thanksgiving, unity), and how it shapes worship and belief.

Know different ways Holy Communion/Eucharist is celebrated (across traditions) and different interpretations of its meaning (e.g., symbolic vs real presence), and why this diversity matters within Christianity.
Know the role and importance of pilgrimage for Christians with two contrasting examples: Lourdes and Iona; why Christians go, typical practices, and spiritual significance.
Understand the celebration of Christmas: what it commemorates (incarnation/birth of Jesus), key traditions, and importance for Christians in Great Britain today.
Understand the celebration of Easter: what it commemorates (crucifixion and resurrection), key traditions, and importance for Christians in Great Britain today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Church in local community: food banks
Sub_topics.description: Understand the role of the Church in the local community through food banks: aims, how they operate, and how they express Christian beliefs about charity and justice.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Church in local community: street pastors
Sub_topics.description: Understand the role of street pastors: what they do, why churches support such outreach, and how it reflects Christian mission and care for others.
Understand the place of mission, evangelism and Church growth: meanings, methods, and why spreading the gospel is important for many Christians.
Know the importance of the worldwide Church in working for reconciliation: what reconciliation means, examples of actions, and theological motivations (forgiveness/peace).
Understand how Christian churches respond to persecution: forms of persecution, practical/spiritual responses, and significance for Christian solidarity and witness.
Know the work of one Christian agency (CAFOD, Christian Aid, or Tearfund): aims, key activities (development, disaster relief, advocacy), and how the work is motivated by Christian teaching.

Topics.Strand: Component 1: The study of religions: beliefs, teachings and practices

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Trinity in the Nicene Creed and Council of Nicaea
Sub_topics.description: Understand Catholic belief in one God as Trinity of persons (Father, Son, Holy Spirit) as expressed in the Nicene Creed; know scriptural origins, and how the belief developed through the Council of Nicaea; significance for Catholic doctrine and worship.

Know Catholic teaching on creation using Genesis 1 and 2: significance for understanding the nature of God, human dignity, and humanity’s relationship with creation; be able to explain different Christian beliefs about creation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Incarnation: Jesus as divine Word, fully God and fully human
Sub_topics.description: Understand Catholic belief in the incarnation: Jesus as incarnate Son and divine Word, fully God and fully human; know scriptural origins and doctrinal significance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Redemption: significance of Jesus’ life, death, resurrection, ascension
Sub_topics.description: Understand redemption in Catholic Christianity: how Jesus’ life, death, resurrection and ascension are significant for salvation and grace; implications for Catholic belief and practice.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Life after death: resurrection, judgement, heaven, hell, purgatory
Sub_topics.description: Know Catholic beliefs about life after death: resurrection, judgement, heaven, hell and purgatory; meanings and significance for moral life, prayer and hope.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Meaning of ‘sacrament’ and sacramental nature of reality
Sub_topics.description: Understand the Catholic meaning and significance of ‘sacrament’ and the importance of the sacramental nature of reality (God’s grace mediated through material signs); how this shapes Catholic worldview and worship.
Know the name, meaning and effects of the sacrament of baptism in Catholic Christianity (initiation, grace, cleansing from sin, incorporation into the Church).
Know the name, meaning and effects of confirmation in Catholic Christianity (strengthening by the Holy Spirit, mature commitment to faith).
Know the name, meaning and effects of reconciliation (confession/penance): forgiveness of sins, restoration of relationship with God and Church.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Seven sacraments: anointing of the sick
Sub_topics.description: Know the name, meaning and effects of anointing of the sick: grace, healing/strength, preparation for death, support in suffering.
Know the name, meaning and effects of matrimony: covenantal union, grace for married life, and its role in family and Church.
Know the name, meaning and effects of holy orders: ordained ministry, service to Church, sacramental authority.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Eucharist as ‘source and summit’ and differing Christian views
Sub_topics.description: Understand the Eucharist in Catholic Christianity as ‘the source and summit of Christian life’: meaning, significance, and awareness of different Christian views about the Eucharist’s meaning and importance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Prayer as raising mind and heart to God
Sub_topics.description: Know Catholic teaching on prayer as ‘the raising of the mind and heart to God’: what prayer is, purposes, and significance in Catholic spiritual life.
Understand formal prayers and informal prayer in Catholic Christianity, including different views about their relative importance; how each supports worship and personal devotion.
Know the meaning and importance of the Lord’s Prayer in Catholic Christianity: themes, use in liturgy and personal prayer, and significance for discipleship.
Understand the Rosary as popular piety: how it is practised, its focus (mysteries of Christ/Mary), and its importance in Catholic devotion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Popular piety: Stations of the Cross
Sub_topics.description: Understand the Stations of the Cross: what it is, how it is practised (especially Lent), and significance for reflection on Jesus’ passion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Pilgrimage (Catholic place of pilgrimage; differing Christian views)
Sub_topics.description: Understand the role and importance of pilgrimage in Catholic Christianity, including study of one place of Roman Catholic pilgrimage; know practices and purposes, and different Christian views about the importance of pilgrimage.
Know the Catholic funeral rite: key elements and beliefs expressed (resurrection, prayer for dead), including why it is significant for mourners and the community.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Love of neighbour in concrete ways (local/national/global)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Catholic belief in the essential duty to ‘love our neighbour’ in concrete ways at local, national and global levels; how this belief motivates social action and charity.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Catholic social teaching: Gaudium et Spes 26
Sub_topics.description: Know Catholic social teaching with reference to Gaudium et Spes paragraph 26: key ideas about human dignity/common good and how they ground action for justice and social welfare.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Catholic teaching on justice, peace and reconciliation
Sub_topics.description: Understand Catholic teaching on justice, peace and reconciliation: principles, motivations (gospel, dignity), and how these shape responses to conflict and inequality.
Know the work of Catholic agencies including CAFOD, Trocaire and Missio: aims and activities (development/relief/mission) and how they express Catholic teaching on love, justice and mission.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mission and evangelism for Catholics (global and Great Britain)
Sub_topics.description: Understand the meaning and significance of mission and evangelism for Catholics today globally and in Great Britain (nationally and locally): why evangelism matters and ways it is carried out.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Society of Saint Vincent de Paul (SVP)
Sub_topics.description: Know the aims and importance of the Society of Saint Vincent de Paul (SVP): practical service to the poor, visiting/support, and how it reflects Catholic social teaching.
Know the aims and importance of either the Corrymeela community or Pax Christi: peace/reconciliation work, how it is influenced by Christian teaching, and its contemporary significance.

Topics.Strand: Component 1: The study of religions: beliefs, teachings and practices

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Brahman: nirguna and saguna; spiritual worlds
Sub_topics.description: Understand brahman in Hinduism: different understandings of brahman as ultimate reality/divine consciousness; distinction between nirguna (without form/qualities) and saguna (manifestation with form/attributes); and awareness of spiritual worlds in Hindu worldview.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Three features of the divine (Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 3.9.1)
Sub_topics.description: Know different understandings of the three features of the divine: everywhere as non-personal (brahman), within the heart, and beyond as a personal loving God; be able to reference Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 3.9.1 in support.
Understand the Tri-murti (Brahma, Vishnu, Shiva): roles (creation/preservation/dissolution), how they relate to brahman and Hindu worship and belief.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Male and female deities (Ganesha, Lakshmi, Hanuman, Saraswati)
Sub_topics.description: Know that the divine is worshipped through many deities; understand characteristics and significance of named deities including Ganesha, Lakshmi, Hanuman and Saraswati; how devotion to deities expresses Hindu beliefs and values.
Understand the concept of avatara (divine descent/incarnation) including Krishna and Rama; why avatars appear, and their significance for bhakti devotion and dharma.
Understand Hindu ideas of matter (prakriti), the three qualities (tri-guna: sattva, rajas, tamas), and illusion (maya); how these concepts explain the material world and spiritual ignorance.
Know Hindu cosmological ideas including reference to Rig Veda 10.129.6–7; how Hindu tradition explores origins/creation as mystery and the significance for beliefs about the universe.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cycle of four ages; many worlds and diverse inhabitants
Sub_topics.description: Understand Hindu cosmology: cycle of four ages (yugas), many worlds, and diverse inhabitants; how cyclical time shapes Hindu worldview and religious goals.
Understand atman: the individual, eternal inner self distinct from material mind and body; how atman relates to brahman in some Hindu philosophies and its importance for liberation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Samsara, karma and moksha (types of liberation)
Sub_topics.description: Understand cycle of birth and death (samsara), law of karma (moral action and reaction), and moksha (liberation); know that Hinduism includes types of liberation and why moksha is the ultimate aim.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Free will and responses to suffering; knowledge and ignorance
Sub_topics.description: Understand Hindu perspectives on individual free will and responses to suffering; the roles of knowledge and ignorance (avidya) in spiritual progress and in explaining human experience.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Personal virtues (ahimsa, respect, empathy, control, humility, love)
Sub_topics.description: Know key Hindu personal virtues including ahimsa, respect, empathy, mind/sense control, humility and love; how virtues support dharma and spiritual progress.
Understand the four aims of human life: dharma, artha, kama, moksha; meanings and how they guide balanced Hindu living and priorities.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Dharma: meanings; sanatana dharma; varnashrama dharma
Sub_topics.description: Understand dharma (duty/righteousness/order): meaning and significance; concepts of sanatana dharma and varnashrama dharma; how dharma varies by life stage and social role and guides ethical life.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Places of worship: home, temple, outdoors, heart
Sub_topics.description: Know Hindu places of worship and their importance: home shrine, temple (mandir), outdoors shrines, and ‘space of the heart’; how worship can be located in multiple places and why this matters in Hindu practice.
Understand havan (fire sacrifice) as a form of worship/ritual: what happens, purposes, and significance in Hindu practice.
Understand puja in Hinduism: key actions (offerings, prayers), purposes, and significance for devotion and relationship with the divine.
Understand arati: meaning (offering of light), how it is performed, and its significance in Hindu worship.
Understand darshan: meaning (seeing/being seen by the deity), how it occurs in temple worship, and its importance in bhakti devotion.
Understand bhajan and kirtan (devotional singing): how they are practised and their significance for devotion and community worship.
Understand japa/mantra repetition: what it involves, purposes (focus, devotion), and significance in Hindu spirituality.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Shaivism vs Vaishnavism: key worship differences and views on importance of worship
Sub_topics.description: Know key differences in worship in Shaivism and Vaishnavism and different Hindu views about the importance of worship; be able to compare practices and theological emphasis (Shiva-focused vs Vishnu/avatars-focused devotion).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Focus of worship: one God (personal or non-personal)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Hindu focus of worship as one God, conceived personally or non-personally (brahman); how monotheistic/monistic interpretations operate within Hinduism and shape worship.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Focus of worship: many deities, guru and elders
Sub_topics.description: Understand worship directed to many deities and respect for guru and elders; significance for guidance, devotion and transmitting tradition.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Focus of worship: holy land, hills and rivers
Sub_topics.description: Know the importance of sacred geography: holy land, hills and rivers; how natural sites become objects of reverence and pilgrimage in Hindu practice.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Focus of worship: sacred plants and animals
Sub_topics.description: Understand the religious significance of sacred plants and animals in Hinduism; how reverence relates to dharma, ahimsa and environmental responsibility.
Understand the murti as a representation of God: role in worship (focus for devotion and darshan), differing Hindu views on images, and significance for practice.
Know origins and meaning of Diwali and its importance for Hindus in Great Britain today; key themes (victory of light/good), typical practices and community significance.
Know origins and meaning of Holi and its importance for Hindus in Great Britain today; key themes, typical celebrations and social significance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Four paths of yoga: karma yoga
Sub_topics.description: Understand the four paths towards yoga (union with the divine) focusing on karma yoga (action): meaning, practices (selfless duty), and importance in Hindu life.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Four paths of yoga: jnana yoga
Sub_topics.description: Understand jnana yoga (knowledge): meaning, practices (study/meditation on truth), and importance for liberation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Four paths of yoga: astanga yoga
Sub_topics.description: Understand astanga yoga (meditation/discipline): meaning and practices (eight-limbed path), and its importance for spiritual development.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Four paths of yoga: bhakti yoga
Sub_topics.description: Understand bhakti yoga (devotion): meaning and practices (worship, prayer), and its importance in Hindu spirituality and community life.
Understand Hindu pilgrimage: role, typical practices and purposes (purification, merit, devotion), and why pilgrimage matters for spiritual life.
Know Varanasi as a sacred site: why it is holy, associated practices and beliefs (Ganges, purification, moksha), and significance for Hindu pilgrimage.
Know Kumbh Mela: what it is, where/when it occurs, practices and purposes, and significance for Hindu community and pilgrimage traditions.
Understand Hindu environmental projects including ‘cow protection’: what they involve, religious reasons (ahimsa, sacredness), and significance for ethics and modern society.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hindu charities promoting well-being, inclusion and women’s rights
Sub_topics.description: Know the work and significance of Hindu charities that promote well-being, social inclusion and women’s rights; how Hindu teachings motivate social action and reform.

Topics.Strand: Component 1: The study of religions: beliefs, teachings and practices

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Sunni six articles of faith and Shi’a five roots (Usul ad-Din)
Sub_topics.description: Know the six articles of faith in Sunni Islam and the five roots of Usul ad-Din in Shi’a Islam; be able to explain key similarities and differences and their significance for Muslim belief and identity.
Understand tawhid (Oneness of God) and be able to reference Qur’an Surah 112; significance for worship (no partners), Muslim identity, and rejection of shirk.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Nature of God: omnipotence, beneficence, mercy, fairness and Adalat
Sub_topics.description: Know Islamic beliefs about the nature of God: omnipotence, beneficence, mercy, fairness; and Adalat (justice) in Shi’a Islam; be able to explain why these attributes matter for faith and moral accountability.
Understand different ideas about God’s relationship with the world: immanence and transcendence; how Muslims may explain God being beyond creation yet close/active within it.
Know beliefs about angels: their nature and role; specific roles of Jibril and Mika’il; significance for revelation, guidance and Muslim worldview.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Predestination and human freedom; Day of Judgement
Sub_topics.description: Understand beliefs about predestination and human freedom and how they relate to the Day of Judgement; how Muslims reconcile divine knowledge/power with human responsibility.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Akhirah: accountability, resurrection, heaven and hell
Sub_topics.description: Know beliefs about akhirah (life after death): human responsibility and accountability, resurrection, heaven and hell; significance for ethics, worship and life choices.
Understand risalah (Prophethood) including role and importance of Adam, Ibrahim and Muhammad; why prophets are needed and how they guide humanity.
Know Qur’an as holy book: how it was revealed, why it is authoritative, how it is used in worship/law, and its status in Muslim life.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Other holy books: Torah, Psalms, Gospel, Scrolls of Abraham
Sub_topics.description: Know Islamic beliefs about other holy books: Torah, Psalms, Gospel, Scrolls of Abraham; their authority within Islam (original revelations) and relationship to Qur’an.
Understand the imamate in Shi’a Islam: role and significance of the Imams as leaders/interpreters, and how this differs from Sunni perspectives on leadership.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Five Pillars and Ten Obligatory Acts (including additional Shi’a duties)
Sub_topics.description: Know that Sunni Islam has Five Pillars and Shi’a Islam has Ten Obligatory Acts; study the Five Pillars and jihad in both Sunni and Shi’a Islam and the additional duties of Shi’a Islam; understand similarities/differences and their impact on practice.
Understand shahadah (declaration of faith): wording/meaning, its place in Muslim practice, and significance for identity and worship.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Salah: times, direction, wudu, rak’ahs, recitations
Sub_topics.description: Know how and why Muslims pray (salah): prescribed times, direction (qiblah), ablution (wudu), movements (rak’ahs) and recitations; significance of discipline and submission to God.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Salah in home, mosque and elsewhere
Sub_topics.description: Understand performance of salah in different contexts (home, mosque, workplace/school) and why communal prayer matters; flexibility and unity of practice.
Know Jummah (Friday prayer): what happens, obligations, sermon (khutbah), and significance for Muslim community and worship.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Sunni vs Shi’a differences in salah; views on importance
Sub_topics.description: Know key differences in the practice of salah in Sunni and Shi’a Islam and different Muslim views about the importance of prayer; be able to compare and explain reasons for differences.
Understand sawm: role and significance of fasting during Ramadan including origins, duties, benefits, exceptions and reasons; how fasting shapes spirituality and moral discipline.
Know the Night of Power (Laylat al-Qadr): significance, relation to Qur’an’s revelation; be able to reference Qur’an 96:1–5; and understand associated worship/practice.
Understand zakah: role and significance of giving alms including origins, how and why it is given, benefits for recipients; and know Khums in Shi’a Islam as additional charitable duty.
Know hajj: role and significance of pilgrimage to Makkah including origins; how hajj is performed; and why it is required for eligible Muslims.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hajj sites and actions: Ka’aba, Mina, Arafat, Muzdalifah
Sub_topics.description: Know key hajj actions at sites: Ka’aba (Makkah), Mina, Arafat, Muzdalifah; what pilgrims do and the significance of each action/site.
Understand different understandings of jihad: meaning and significance of greater jihad (inner struggle) and lesser jihad (external struggle); how these concepts shape Muslim ethics and identity.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Lesser jihad: origins, influence and conditions
Sub_topics.description: Know origins, influence and conditions for declaring lesser jihad; ethical constraints and debates; how different Muslims interpret its legitimacy.
Know origins and meanings of Id-ul-Adha and its importance for Muslims in Great Britain today; how it links to Ibrahim and hajj; key practices (prayer, sacrifice, charity).
Know origins and meanings of Id-ul-Fitr and its importance for Muslims in Great Britain today; how it marks the end of Ramadan; key practices (prayer, celebration, charity).
Know origins and meanings of Ashura and its importance for Muslims in Great Britain today; differing Sunni/Shi’a commemorations and significance (especially for Shi’a history and identity).

Topics.Strand: Component 1: The study of religions: beliefs, teachings and practices

Sub_topics.description: Know Jewish belief that God is one (monotheism): significance for worship, Shema, and Jewish identity.
Understand belief in God as Creator: how creation belief shapes Jewish attitudes to the world, responsibility and gratitude.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: God as Law-Giver and Judge; loving and merciful
Sub_topics.description: Know Jewish beliefs about God as Law-Giver and Judge, loving and merciful; how these attributes relate to covenant, Torah obedience, repentance and justice.
Understand the concept of Shekhinah (divine presence): what it means, where it is experienced (e.g., worship/community), and its significance in Jewish life.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Life after death: judgement and resurrection
Sub_topics.description: Know Jewish beliefs about life after death including judgement and resurrection; diversity of belief within Judaism and significance for moral responsibility.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Messiah: nature and role; differing views
Sub_topics.description: Understand the nature and role of the Messiah in Judaism, including different views on the Messiah’s role/importance (personal messiah vs messianic age, Orthodox/Reform perspectives) and implications for hope and identity.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Covenant with Abraham and promised land (Genesis 12:1–3)
Sub_topics.description: Know the promised land and the Covenant with Abraham with reference to Genesis 12:1–3; significance for Jewish identity, relationship with God, and understanding of chosen people.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Covenant at Sinai; Moses and Ten Commandments (Exodus 20:1–17)
Sub_topics.description: Understand the Covenant at Sinai and its importance, including role of Moses and the Ten Commandments with reference to Exodus 20:1–17; how this covenant shapes Torah observance and moral life.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Key moral principles: justice, healing the world, charity, kindness
Sub_topics.description: Know key Jewish moral principles including justice, healing the world (tikkun olam), charity and kindness to others; how they guide ethical behaviour and community action.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Sanctity of human life and Pikuach Nefesh
Sub_topics.description: Understand the sanctity of human life in Judaism, including ‘saving a life’ (Pikuach Nefesh): meaning, how it can override other laws, and ethical implications.
Understand the relationship between free will and the 613 mitzvot: why Jews choose to obey commandments and how obedience expresses covenant relationship.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mitzvot between man and God vs between man and man
Sub_topics.description: Know mitzvot between man and God and mitzvot between man and man: differences, examples, and why both types are important in Jewish religious and ethical life.
Understand the synagogue and its importance in Judaism: as place of worship, community, learning and identity.
Know the design feature bimah (reading platform): purpose and associated practices (Torah reading) and why it matters in worship.
Know aron hakodesh (ark): purpose (Torah storage), associated practices (standing, facing ark), and significance for reverence to Torah.
Know ner tamid (ever burning light): symbolism, placement, and significance for God’s presence/continuity.
Understand differences between Orthodox and Reform synagogues in design and associated practices (e.g., seating, gender separation, language/music); significance for diversity within Judaism.
Know public acts of worship: synagogue services in Orthodox and Reform synagogues; key features and how they express beliefs and community identity.
Understand significance of prayer in Judaism including the Amidah (standing prayer): structure/themes and why it is central to daily worship.
Know Shabbat: practices in home and synagogue, meaning (rest, covenant), and significance for Jewish identity and family/community life.
Understand worship in the home and private prayer: examples (blessings, daily prayers), importance of family religious life and continuity.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Tenakh and Talmud: study, use and significance
Sub_topics.description: Know Tenakh (written law/scriptures) and Talmud (oral law): their study, use and significance in daily life; how they guide belief, practice and ethical decisions.
Know ceremonies associated with birth including Brit Milah: what happens, covenant meaning, and significance in Jewish community and identity.
Understand Bar and Bat Mitzvah: purpose (coming of age), rituals and responsibilities, and significance for Jewish identity and Torah observance.
Know Jewish marriage ceremony: key elements (ketubah, chuppah, blessings), meaning and significance for covenant and family life.
Understand Jewish mourning rituals: practices (e.g., sitting shiva) and their significance for community support, respect and belief about life/death.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Dietary laws: significance and differing views
Sub_topics.description: Know Jewish dietary laws and their significance; understand different Jewish views about their importance (Orthodox/Reform); how dietary laws support identity and holiness.
Know meanings of kosher and trefah: permitted vs forbidden foods and rules, and their role in Jewish daily life.
Understand the rule of separation of milk and meat: origins/interpretations, practical application, and significance for observant Jews.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur (origins and meaning)
Sub_topics.description: Know origins and meaning of Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur and their importance for Jews in Great Britain today: themes of judgement, repentance, forgiveness; key practices and significance.
Know origins and meaning of Pesach and its importance for Jews in Great Britain today: Exodus remembrance, key practices (Seder, unleavened bread) and significance for identity and freedom.

Topics.Strand: Component 1: The study of religions: beliefs, teachings and practices

Sub_topics.description: Know the content and significance of the Mool Mantra as expression of the nature of God; be able to reference Guru Granth Sahib (GGS) 1a; and explain how it shapes Sikh belief and identity.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: God as Creator: immanent and separate aspects
Sub_topics.description: Understand Sikh belief in God as Creator, including different aspects of God’s relationship with creation: God shown in/through the universe and God as separate from the universe; implications for worship and worldview.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Human life as opportunity to unite with God; Sikh virtues
Sub_topics.description: Understand Sikh beliefs about the nature of human life as an opportunity to unite with God; know Sikh virtues (wisdom, truthful living, justice, temperance, self-control, patience, courage, humility, contentment) and how they support spiritual progress.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Karma, rebirth and aim of mukti (positive and negative aspects)
Sub_topics.description: Know Sikh beliefs in karma and rebirth and the aim of mukti; understand the meaning of mukti including positive and negative aspects; and why liberation matters in Sikh life.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Five khands and barriers to mukti
Sub_topics.description: Understand the five stages of liberation (five khands) and barriers to mukti: illusion, self-centredness, lust, anger, greed, worldly attachment, pride; how Sikhs overcome these through discipline and devotion.
Know the importance of being gurmukh (God-centred) rather than manmukh (man-centred) and the elimination of pride/ego (haumai); implications for ethical and spiritual living.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Oneness of humanity and equality (including equality of women)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Sikh belief in the oneness of humanity and equality of all, including complete equality of women with men; how this belief shapes Sikh ethics and community life.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Equality in Guru stories (Nanak, Gobind Singh)
Sub_topics.description: Know how equality is expressed in stories of the lives of the Gurus, including Guru Nanak and Guru Gobind Singh; significance for Sikh identity and practice today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Equality in Guru Granth Sahib and in Sikhism today
Sub_topics.description: Understand how equality is expressed in the Guru Granth Sahib and in Sikhism today; be able to apply teachings to contemporary issues and practices.
Know sewa (service) as priority in Sikhism, including physical (tan), mental (man) and material (dhan) service; significance for community, ethics and worship.
Understand role and importance of the sangat: community worship, support, learning; and significance for Sikh identity and practice.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Gurdwara features: design, furniture, artefacts (palki, takht)
Sub_topics.description: Know religious features of the gurdwara (design, furniture, artefacts) and associated practices; include importance of the palki and takht and how these express reverence for the Guru Granth Sahib and Sikh authority.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Role of the gurdwara in the Sikh community
Sub_topics.description: Understand the role of the gurdwara within the Sikh community: worship, education, charity, identity, and social support.
Know the role of prayer in the home and be able to reference GGS 305:4; understand how daily devotion supports spirituality and ethical living.
Understand the role and importance of the akhand path (continuous reading of the Guru Granth Sahib): when it is performed, purposes, and significance for community and devotion.
Understand langar: meaning and significance as an expression of sewa and equality; how it operates and its social/religious importance.
Know the significance of meditating on the name of God (nam japna) in daily life and in the gurdwara; how it supports spiritual focus and union with God.
Know origins and significance of Vaisakhi (Baisakhi) and its importance for Sikhs in Great Britain today; link to Khalsa formation and community identity.
Know origins and significance of Divali for Sikhs and its importance in Great Britain today; how Sikh observance may differ from Hindu festival focus.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Gurpurbs: Guru Nanak’s birthday; India vs GB celebration differences
Sub_topics.description: Understand gurpurbs including Guru Nanak’s birthday: origins, significance, typical practices; and differences in how gurpurbs are celebrated in India and Great Britain.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Visiting historical gurdwaras: Golden Temple (Harimandir Sahib)
Sub_topics.description: Know the importance of visiting Sikh historical gurdwaras, including the Golden Temple (Harimandir Sahib) in Amritsar; significance for devotion, identity and pilgrimage.
Know Sikh birth and naming ceremonies: what happens, meanings, and significance for welcoming child into faith community.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Amrit Sanskar initiation; Khalsa and five Ks
Sub_topics.description: Understand Amrit Sanskar: initiation ceremony; meaning and importance of the Khalsa and the five Ks; how initiation shapes discipline, identity and commitment.
Know different Sikh perspectives of sahajdhari and amritdhari Sikhs: differing commitments to Khalsa discipline and five Ks, and how this diversity appears in Sikh practice.
Understand the significance and use of the names Singh and Kaur: meanings, equality, and identity within Sikh community.

Topics.Strand: Component 2: Thematic studies (Religious, philosophical and ethical studies)

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Human sexuality (heterosexual and same sex relationships)
Sub_topics.description: Understand issues of human sexuality including heterosexual and same sex relationships; be able to describe contrasting religious and non-religious perspectives in contemporary British society and apply teachings from Christianity (main tradition) and at least one other religion where appropriate.

Understand religious, philosophical and ethical teachings and arguments about sexual relationships before and outside of marriage; be able to compare contrasting views (Christianity and at least one other religion) and evaluate arguments used in British society.

Understand teachings and arguments about contraception and family planning; explain contrasting beliefs with reference to Christianity and one or more other religious traditions; consider ethical reasoning and impact in modern Britain.
Understand the nature and purpose of marriage in religious traditions and society: reasons, commitments, and ethical significance; compare differing beliefs and evaluate arguments.

Understand teachings and arguments about same-sex marriage and cohabitation; explain contrasting beliefs with reference to Christianity and one or more other religions; evaluate ethical reasoning and social impact in Britain.
Understand divorce including reasons for divorce and remarrying; compare religious views and practices; consider impacts on individuals and families in contemporary society.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ethical arguments about divorce: sanctity of vows vs compassion
Sub_topics.description: Analyse ethical arguments related to divorce, including arguments based on the sanctity of marriage vows and compassion; apply religious teachings and evaluate contrasting conclusions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Nature of families: roles of parents and children
Sub_topics.description: Understand the nature of families including roles of parents and children; how religious teachings shape responsibilities, upbringing, and family relationships; and contrasting perspectives in modern Britain.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Nature of families: extended and nuclear families
Sub_topics.description: Understand extended and nuclear family structures; religious and social views on their value; and contemporary British perspectives.
Understand procreation as a purpose of families: religious significance, ethical debates, and changing social attitudes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Purpose of families: stability and protection of children
Sub_topics.description: Understand family purpose in providing stability and protection for children; religious arguments for family responsibility and safeguarding; and contemporary issues.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Purpose of families: educating children in a faith
Sub_topics.description: Understand educating children in a faith as a family purpose: methods (home, worship, rites), importance for religious continuity, and debates in pluralistic Britain.

Understand contemporary family issue of same-sex parents: religious and ethical debates, contrasting perspectives (Christianity and at least one other religion), and implications for children and society.
Understand polygamy as a contemporary family issue: religious and ethical arguments, legal/social context in Britain, and contrasting perspectives.
Understand religious and social views on the roles of men and women in family and society; sources of beliefs, and contrasting perspectives in Britain.
Understand gender equality: religious teachings and ethical arguments for/against equality in roles and status; contemporary British debates and impacts.
Understand gender prejudice and discrimination with examples; religious and ethical responses; how beliefs influence attitudes and actions in modern Britain.

Topics.Strand: Component 2: Thematic studies (Religious, philosophical and ethical studies)

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Origins of the universe: religious teachings and interpretations
Sub_topics.description: Understand religious teachings about the origins of the universe and different interpretations (e.g., literal vs non-literal); how these shape belief about God/ultimate reality and creation.
Understand the relationship between scientific views such as the Big Bang theory and religious views on origins; how believers may reconcile or oppose scientific explanations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Value of the world: stewardship, dominion, responsibility, awe and wonder
Sub_topics.description: Understand the value of the world and duty to protect it, including religious teaching about stewardship, dominion, responsibility, awe and wonder; apply teachings to environmental ethics.

Understand environmental use and abuse including natural resources and pollution; religious and ethical arguments about sustainability and human responsibility; contemporary British/global perspectives.

Understand ethical debates about animal experimentation; explain contrasting beliefs with reference to Christianity and one or more other religions; evaluate arguments about benefits, rights and suffering.
Understand religious and ethical issues about using animals for food (dietary rules, welfare, vegetarianism); evaluate contrasting perspectives and arguments.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Origins of human life: religious teachings and interpretations
Sub_topics.description: Understand religious teachings about the origins of human life and different interpretations; how these influence beliefs about purpose, human dignity and moral responsibility.
Understand the relationship between scientific views such as evolution and religious views about human origins; differing perspectives (compatibility vs conflict) and implications for faith.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Sanctity of life and quality of life
Sub_topics.description: Understand concepts of sanctity of life and quality of life; how they are used in ethical debates and how religious teachings support different conclusions.

Understand abortion debates including situations when the mother’s life is at risk; explain contrasting beliefs with reference to Christianity and one or more other religions; consider legal and social context.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ethical arguments about abortion: sanctity vs quality of life
Sub_topics.description: Analyse ethical arguments related to abortion including those based on sanctity of life and quality of life; apply religious teachings and evaluate competing arguments.
Understand euthanasia: definitions, types, ethical debates; explain contrasting beliefs with reference to Christianity and one or more other religions; evaluate arguments.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Afterlife beliefs and value of human life
Sub_topics.description: Understand how beliefs about death and an afterlife impact beliefs about the value of human life; apply religious teachings to ethical decisions about life and death.

Topics.Strand: Component 2: Thematic studies (Religious, philosophical and ethical studies)
Topics.Topic_name: Theme C: The existence of God and revelation

Sub_topics.description: Understand the Design argument for God’s existence: core reasoning (order/purpose implies designer), common forms (e.g., analogy), and be able to evaluate strengths and weaknesses.
Understand the First Cause (cosmological) argument: reasoning that the universe requires a first cause; evaluate strengths and weaknesses including challenges (infinite regress, cause of God).
Understand the argument from miracles as evidence for God; evaluate strengths and weaknesses including alternative explanations and reliability of testimony.
Know one example of a miracle and why it is considered miraculous; be able to use it to support or challenge belief in God and evaluate competing interpretations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Evil and suffering as argument against God
Sub_topics.description: Understand how evil and suffering are used as arguments against the existence of God; distinguish logical/emotional challenges and evaluate religious responses.
Understand arguments based on science against the existence of God (e.g., naturalistic explanations); evaluate how atheism/humanism and religious believers use scientific reasoning in debate.

Understand special revelation as a source of knowledge about the divine, focusing on visions; know what visions are, why they are significant, and be able to discuss contrasting perspectives in Christianity and non-religious beliefs (atheism/humanism).
Know one example of a vision and its claimed meaning; evaluate religious significance and alternative explanations (psychological, deception, misunderstanding).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Enlightenment as knowledge of the divine
Sub_topics.description: Understand enlightenment as a source of knowledge about the divine/ultimate reality (especially in non-theistic traditions); how it is experienced and why it is authoritative for believers.
Understand general revelation: how nature and scripture may be used as ways of understanding the divine; compare nature-based arguments and scriptural authority.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Divine attributes from revelation: omnipotent and omniscient
Sub_topics.description: Understand ideas about the divine arising from revelation/enlightenment including omnipotence and omniscience; how these attributes are inferred and debated.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Divine attributes from revelation: personal and impersonal
Sub_topics.description: Understand ideas about the divine as personal and impersonal; how different religions interpret ultimate reality and implications for worship and ethics.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Divine attributes from revelation: immanent and transcendent
Sub_topics.description: Understand ideas about the divine as immanent and transcendent; how these concepts relate to revelation and religious experience.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Value of general vs special revelation and enlightenment
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate the value of general and special revelation and enlightenment as sources of knowledge about the divine; include issues of conflicting ideas about the divine and reliability of experiences.

Understand and evaluate alternative explanations for visions/miracles/revelation experiences, including psychological/sociological causes and the possibility that claimants were lying or mistaken; implications for religious belief.

Topics.Strand: Component 2: Thematic studies (Religious, philosophical and ethical studies)
Topics.Topic_name: Theme D: Religion, peace and conflict

Sub_topics.description: Understand meanings and significance of peace in religious ethics; how peace relates to justice, reconciliation and conflict resolution.
Understand meanings and significance of justice in religious ethics; how justice can support peace-making and shape views on punishment/war.
Understand meanings and significance of forgiveness; religious teachings about forgiving others and its role in reconciliation and peace.
Understand meanings and significance of reconciliation: restoring relationships after conflict; religious motivations and examples in peace-making.

Understand violence including violent protest: religious and ethical arguments about when, if ever, violence is justified; explain contrasting beliefs with reference to Christianity and one or more other religions.
Understand terrorism: definitions, motivations, religious and non-religious perspectives; evaluate religious teachings used to condemn or (mis)justify terrorism.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reasons for war: greed, self-defence, retaliation
Sub_topics.description: Know reasons for war including greed, self-defence and retaliation; evaluate these reasons ethically and with reference to religious teaching.
Understand the just war theory and criteria for a just war (e.g., just cause, last resort, proportionality, legitimate authority); apply criteria to evaluate conflicts.
Understand the idea of holy war: what makes a war ‘holy’ in some perspectives, religious debates and criticisms, and why this concept is controversial in modern society.
Understand pacifism: meaning, religious arguments for pacifism, and contrasting views that allow war/violence; apply to contemporary issues.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Religion and belief as causes of war and violence today
Sub_topics.description: Analyse how religion and belief can be causes of war and violence in the contemporary world; include conflicts, identity, political factors, and evaluate whether religion is the main cause.
Understand nuclear weapons including nuclear deterrence: ethical arguments for/against deterrence, religious perspectives, and implications for peace and security.
Understand weapons of mass destruction and ethical/religious debates about their use; explain contrasting beliefs and evaluate arguments about proportionality and civilian harm.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Religion and peace-making: individuals influenced by religion
Sub_topics.description: Know religion and peace-making in the contemporary world including the work of individuals influenced by religious teaching; how beliefs motivate reconciliation and non-violence.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Religious responses to victims of war (one present-day organisation)
Sub_topics.description: Understand religious responses to victims of war including the work of one present-day religious organisation: forms of support, motivations, and impact.

Topics.Strand: Component 2: Thematic studies (Religious, philosophical and ethical studies)
Topics.Topic_name: Theme E: Religion, crime and punishment

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Good and evil intentions and actions; can it be good to cause suffering?
Sub_topics.description: Understand issues of good and evil intentions and actions, including whether it can ever be good to cause suffering; apply religious teachings and ethical reasoning.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reasons for crime: poverty and upbringing
Sub_topics.description: Understand reasons for crime including poverty and upbringing; religious and ethical responses to offenders and social responsibility.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reasons for crime: mental health problems and addiction
Sub_topics.description: Understand reasons for crime including mental health problems and addiction; evaluate views on blame, treatment, and compassion/justice in response.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reasons for crime: greed and hate
Sub_topics.description: Understand reasons for crime including greed and hate; religious teachings on temptation, sin, prejudice; and ethical responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reasons for crime: opposition to an unjust law
Sub_topics.description: Understand crime motivated by opposition to an unjust law (civil disobedience); evaluate when, if ever, breaking the law is justified using religious and ethical reasoning.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Views about people who break the law for these reasons
Sub_topics.description: Analyse views about offenders who break the law due to poverty, addiction, hate, or protest; compare religious perspectives on responsibility, compassion, justice and social reform.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Types of crime: hate crimes, theft, murder
Sub_topics.description: Understand views about different types of crime including hate crimes, theft and murder; how seriousness is judged and religious responses to victims and offenders.
Understand retribution as an aim of punishment: meaning (deserved punishment), religious and ethical support/critique.
Understand deterrence as an aim of punishment: meaning (prevent future crime), effectiveness debates, and religious/ethical perspectives.
Understand reformation as an aim of punishment: meaning (rehabilitation), how it may be achieved, and religious/ethical arguments for reformative justice.
Understand prison as treatment of criminals: purposes, advantages/criticisms, and religious/ethical views on humane treatment and rehabilitation.
Understand corporal punishment: what it is, arguments for/against, and be able to explain contrasting religious perspectives (Christianity and at least one other religion).
Understand community service as punishment: aims, benefits, and how it relates to reparation and rehabilitation; religious/ethical evaluation.
Understand forgiveness in the context of crime and punishment: religious teachings, impact on victims/offenders, and debates about justice vs mercy.
Understand the death penalty: what it is, arguments for/against, and explain contrasting beliefs with reference to Christianity and one or more other religions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ethical arguments about death penalty: utility vs sanctity of life
Sub_topics.description: Analyse ethical arguments related to the death penalty including those based on the principle of utility and sanctity of life; apply religious teachings and evaluate conclusions.

Topics.Strand: Component 2: Thematic studies (Religious, philosophical and ethical studies)
Topics.Topic_name: Theme F: Religion, human rights and social justice

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Prejudice and discrimination in religion and belief (women; same sex relationships)
Sub_topics.description: Understand prejudice and discrimination in religion and belief, including status and treatment within religion of women and those in same sex relationships; evaluate religious teachings and contemporary British perspectives.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Equality and freedom of religion/belief; freedom of religious expression
Sub_topics.description: Understand issues of equality and freedom of religion and belief including freedom of religious expression; explain contrasting beliefs (Christianity and one or more other religions) and evaluate debates in Britain.
Understand human rights and responsibilities that come with rights, including responsibility to respect the rights of others; ethical reasoning and religious perspectives.
Understand social justice: meaning, aims (fairness, equal opportunity), and how religions campaign for justice; evaluate effectiveness and challenges.
Understand racial prejudice and discrimination: causes and examples; religious and ethical responses; links to human dignity and equality.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ethical arguments about racial discrimination (including positive discrimination)
Sub_topics.description: Analyse ethical arguments related to racial discrimination including positive discrimination; include arguments based on ideals of equality and justice; apply religious teachings and evaluate outcomes.
Understand religious and ethical teachings on the right attitude to wealth (stewardship, generosity, dangers of greed); apply to contemporary society.
Understand different uses of wealth and ethical evaluation of spending, saving, investing and giving; religious perspectives on responsible use.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Responsibilities of wealth: tackle poverty and causes
Sub_topics.description: Understand responsibilities of those with wealth, including duty to tackle poverty and its causes; religious teachings on charity/justice and social responsibility.
Understand exploitation of those living in poverty including fair pay issues; religious and ethical arguments for living wage/justice in employment.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Exploitation in poverty: excessive interest on loans
Sub_topics.description: Understand exploitation via excessive interest on loans (usury/debt traps); religious and ethical perspectives and contemporary examples.
Understand people-trafficking as exploitation of those in poverty: causes, ethical wrongness, and religious responses/campaigns.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Responsibilities of those in poverty to help themselves
Sub_topics.description: Understand debates about responsibilities of those living in poverty to help themselves overcome difficulties; evaluate fairness, structural causes, and religious ethical perspectives on support and empowerment.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Charity and giving money to those in poverty
Sub_topics.description: Understand charity including issues related to giving money to those living in poverty: effective charity, dependency concerns, justice vs charity; religious teachings and evaluation.

Topics.Strand: Component 2: Thematic studies (Textual studies: St Mark’s Gospel)
Topics.Topic_name: Theme G: St Mark's gospel – the life of Jesus

Sub_topics.description: Know Mark 1:1–8: John the Baptist’s preparation for Jesus’ ministry, key content (message, baptism, prophecy), and significance for understanding Jesus’ mission and early Christian belief.
Know Mark 1:9–13: Jesus’ baptism and temptation; significance for identity as Son of God, beginning of ministry, and themes of obedience and testing.
Know Mark 2:1–12: healing of the paralysed man; key themes (forgiveness of sins, authority), and significance for Christology and responses to Jesus.
Know Mark 5:21–24a, 35–43: Jairus’ daughter; significance for Jesus’ power over death, faith, and interpretation of miracles.
Know Mark 6:1–6: rejection at Nazareth; significance for themes of unbelief, familiarity, and challenges to Jesus’ authority.
Know Mark 6:30–44: feeding of the five thousand; key themes (compassion, provision), and significance including historicity debates and symbolic interpretations.
Know Mark 8:27–33: confession at Caesarea Philippi and rebuke of Peter; significance for Jesus’ identity (Messiah) and the nature of his mission (suffering).
Know Mark 9:2–9: transfiguration; significance for Jesus’ identity, revelation of glory, and disciples’ understanding.
Know Mark 10:32–34: Jesus’ passion prediction; significance for foreknowledge, purpose of death, and discipleship.
Know Mark 10:35–45: request of James and John; significance for servant leadership, sacrifice, and meaning of discipleship.
Know Mark 10:46–52: healing of Bartimaeus; significance for faith, discipleship, and recognition of Jesus’ identity.
Know Mark 11:1–11: entry into Jerusalem; significance for messianic expectations, symbolism, and escalation towards conflict.
Know Mark 14:12–26: the Last Supper; significance for covenant, Eucharist interpretations, and understanding Jesus’ death.
Know Mark 14:32–52: Jesus in Gethsemane; significance for Jesus’ humanity, obedience, and disciples’ failure.
Know Mark 14:53, 57–65: trial before Jewish authorities; significance for charges against Jesus, identity claims, and injustice themes.
Know Mark 15:1–15: trial before Pilate; significance for political/religious power, Barabbas, and path to crucifixion.
Know Mark 15:21–47: crucifixion and burial; significance for atonement interpretations, suffering, and historical claims.
Know Mark 16:1–8: empty tomb; significance for resurrection belief and differing explanations; awareness of interpretative debates.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Titles: Son of Man, Son of God, Christ (Messiah), Son of David (1st century meaning)
Sub_topics.description: Understand titles Son of Man, Son of God, Christ (Messiah) and Son of David: meaning for 1st century Jews and for Jesus; how titles shape understanding of identity and mission in Mark.
Understand significance for 21st century Christians of Jesus’ understanding of titles Son of Man, Son of God, Christ (Messiah) and Son of David; implications for faith, worship and discipleship.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Jesus as teacher and miracle worker; historicity debates
Sub_topics.description: Understand Mark’s portrayal of Jesus as teacher and miracle worker; be able to explain contrasting views on the historicity of miracle stories and how this affects authority and belief.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Last Supper: differing beliefs about meaning of words/actions
Sub_topics.description: Understand differing beliefs about the meaning of Jesus’ words and actions at the Last Supper (e.g., symbolism, covenant, Eucharist theology); implications for Christian practice.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Death and resurrection: differing beliefs; empty tomb explanations
Sub_topics.description: Understand differing beliefs about the significance of Jesus’ death and resurrection and different explanations for the empty tomb; be able to compare interpretations within Christianity and evaluate them.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Authority of Mark’s Gospel vs secular contemporary authority
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate differing views on the authority of St Mark’s Gospel relating to the life of Jesus in relation to challenges posed by secular sources of contemporary authority (history, science, media); implications for belief and practice.

Topics.Strand: Component 2: Thematic studies (Textual studies: St Mark’s Gospel)
Topics.Topic_name: Theme H: St Mark's Gospel as a source of religious, moral and spiritual truths

Sub_topics.description: Know Mark 4:1–9, 14–20: parable of the sower and Jesus’ explanation; understand teachings about hearing/receiving the word, discipleship and the Kingdom of God.
Know Mark 4:26–29: parable of the growing seed; understand teaching about Kingdom growth, divine action and patience/faith.
Know Mark 4:30–32: parable of the mustard seed; understand teachings about small beginnings and expansive Kingdom impact.
Know Mark 10:13–16: Jesus and the children; understand teachings about humility, welcome and entering the Kingdom of God.
Know Mark 10:17–27: the rich man; understand teachings about wealth, discipleship and salvation, and moral implications for Christians.
Know Mark 12:28–34: the greatest commandment; understand teachings on love of God and neighbour and their moral significance.
Know Mark 1:40–45: healing of the man with leprosy; understand Jesus’ attitude to purity/exclusion and its moral implications.
Know Mark 2:13–17: call of Levi and meals with ‘sinners’; understand inclusion, forgiveness and critique of hypocrisy.
Know Mark 7:24–30: healing of the Syro-Phoenician woman’s daughter; understand themes of faith, outsiders and widening mission.
Know Mark 9:14–29: healing of the boy; understand themes of faith, prayer and disciples’ limitations.
Know Mark 12:41–44: widow’s offering; understand teachings about generosity, sacrifice and true devotion.
Know Mark 14:1–9: anointing at Bethany; understand themes of devotion, misunderstanding, and preparation for death.
Know Mark 1:16–20: call of the first disciples; understand immediate response, discipleship commitment and mission.
Know Mark 5:24b–34: healing of the woman with haemorrhage; understand faith, healing, purity and inclusion themes.
Know Mark 6:7–13: mission of the Twelve; understand discipleship in action, authority, dependence and proclamation.
Know Mark 8:34–38 and 10:28–31: teachings on cost and rewards of discipleship; understand self-denial, taking up the cross, and promises of reward/persecution.
Know Mark 14:27–31 and 66–72: Peter’s denials; understand human weakness, forgiveness, and discipleship challenges.
Know Mark 16:14–20: commission and ascension; understand mission mandate, belief/unbelief, and authority for Christian evangelism.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Significance of key events for Jesus’ day and 21st century
Sub_topics.description: Understand significance and importance for Jesus, for people of his day and for 21st century people of key events recorded in Mark; how narrative conveys religious, moral and spiritual truths.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Kingdom of God: present vs future; inner state vs community
Sub_topics.description: Understand different ways the Kingdom of God might be understood: present reality vs future hope; personal inner state vs community; implications for Christian ethics and church life.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: 1st century attitudes to disregarded people and Jesus’ attitudes
Sub_topics.description: Know reasons for 1st century attitudes (and those of Jesus) to those disregarded by society; social/purity factors and how Jesus’ actions challenge norms.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Christian significance of Jesus’ attitudes to disregarded people
Sub_topics.description: Understand significance and importance for Christians of Jesus’ attitudes to those disregarded by society; implications for inclusion, charity, social justice and mission today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Discipleship: significance for disciples and 21st century Christians
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate different views on significance and importance of discipleship for Jesus’ disciples and for 21st century Christians, using incidents about disciples and Jesus’ teaching.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Faith: nature and importance in Mark
Sub_topics.description: Understand different views on the nature and importance of faith as seen in St Mark’s Gospel; how faith relates to healing, discipleship and salvation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Authority of Jesus’ teaching in Mark vs secular authority
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate differing views on the authority of Jesus’ teaching as recorded by Mark in relation to challenges posed by secular sources of contemporary authority; implications for moral decision-making.
